[[File:Mikael Storsjö.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Storsjö in 2009]] '''Mikael Storsjö''' (born December 22, 1957) is a Finnish [[Information Technology|IT entrepreneur]], journalist and [[non-governmental organization]] activist. He is a board member of [[FINROSFORUM]].<ref>{{cite web |title=EFFI:n hallitus |url= http://www.effi.org/yhdistys/hallitus.html |publisher= EFFI |accessdate=25 February 2011|language=Finnish}}</ref> He is known for his clashes with the Finnish and Swedish authorities concerning the [[Internet hosting service|hosting]] of the [[Kavkaz Center]]'s website on his [[Server (computing)|server]]s. In 2011–2012, he has also been involved in a court case, in which he was found guilty of arranging illegal entry into Finland of 25 [[Chechens]].<ref name=HS>{{cite news|title=Court of Appeals hands down suspended sentence for helping Chechens enter Finland illegally|url=http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Court+of+Appeals+hands+down+suspended+sentence+for+helping+Chechens+enter+Finland+illegally/1329104310775|accessdate=June 20, 2012|newspaper=[[Helsingin Sanomat]]|date=June 16, 2012}}</ref>
==Hosting of Kavkaz Center in Finland== In [[Finland]] Storsjö became a public figure in October 2004, when the [[Lithuania|Lithuanian government]] banned the Kavkaz Center website, and Storsjö moved the website to his server in Finland. The [[Finnish Security Intelligence Service]] (FSIS) then confiscated his servers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tsetseenisivut julkaistiin sananvapauden takia ‘Freedom of speech as motivation for publishing the Chechen website |url=http://www.mbnet.fi/uutiset/index.asp?Uutinen=1577 |publisher=Mikrobitti |accessdate=25 February 2011 |language=Finnish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929071203/http://www.mbnet.fi/uutiset/index.asp?Uutinen=1577 |archivedate=29 September 2011 |df= }}</ref>
In the public discussion that then ensued, there was a general agreement that the authorities had violated the freedom of speech with their actions.<ref>{{cite web |title=Journalists complain of blow to Finnish freedom of expression |url=http://www.hs.fi/english/article/1076154535007 |publisher= [[Helsingin Sanomat]] |accessdate=15 November 2004 }}</ref>
After these events, Storsjö has continued to support Kavkaz Center by offering them the use of his servers both in Finland and in [[Sweden]].
Kavkaz Center is an internet news agency which publishes news on [[Chechnya]] and the [[Caucasus]] region from the point of view of the [[Mujahideen]] warriors. It is believed that the Kavkaz Center is in the control of the “minister of public relations” of the [[Chechen Republic of Ichkeria]], [[Movladi Udugov]]. Udugov belongs to the Islamic warriors of the region.<ref>Chechnya Weekly Volume 7, Issue 38 (October 05, 2006), Andrei Smirnov: Dokku Umarov: Between Jihad and the Struggle for Freedom: “This rhetoric of Dokku Umarov could not be ignored by the Islamic wing of the insurgency. The Kavkaz-Center website, which is controlled by Movladi Udugov, started to censor Umarov’s statements.” {{cite web |title= Dokku Umarov: Between Jihad and the Struggle for Freedom |url= http://jamestown.org/chechnya_weekly/article.php?articleid=2372592 |publisher= The Jamestown Foundation |accessdate= not accessible on 25 February 2011 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070930181057/http://www.jamestown.org/chechnya_weekly/article.php?articleid=2372592# |archive-date= 2007-09-30 |dead-url= yes |df= }}</ref>
The publishing activities of the Kavkaz Center are known to be a sore point for [[Russia]], which is involved in a war in the area. Russia has tried to resort to diplomatic means in order to prevent the website from being hosted in various countries, including Sweden and Finland. The Russian foreign minister [[Sergei Lavrov]] has said that the website is being used to incite people to conduct terrorist activities.<ref>{{cite web |title= Separatist website finds a home in Sweden, Chechnya Weekly Volume 5, Issue 43 |url= http://www.jamestown.org/chechnya_weekly/article.php?articleid=2371326 |publisher= The Jamestown Foundation |accessdate= not accessible on 25 February 2011 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070930181042/http://www.jamestown.org/chechnya_weekly/article.php?articleid=2371326# |archive-date= 2007-09-30 |dead-url= yes |df= }}</ref> Those who defend the website, however, argue that mediation of news based on pluralistic values is the only way that both parties of the conflict can make their views known to the public.<ref>{{cite web |title= Sananvapaus joutui pikaoikeuteen ‘Freedom of speech subjected to deliberation of an instant court’ |url= http://www.finrosforum.fi/Document/KC/HS_21_10_2004_pikaoikeus.htm |publisher= [[Helsingin Sanomat]] |accessdate= 17 July 2007 |language= Finnish |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070928051006/http://www.finrosforum.fi/Document/KC/HS_21_10_2004_pikaoikeus.htm |archivedate= 28 September 2007 |df= }}</ref>
The Kavkaz Center website was closed in [[Lithuania]] in the autumn of 2004, on request by [[Russia]], after the [[Beslan school hostage crisis]], when the website had published a message from [[Shamil Basayev]], in which he assumed responsibility for the attack.<ref>{{cite web |title=Kremlin pressures Lithuania to close pro-Chechen website |url=http://www.ifex.org/es/content/view/full/61405/ |publisher=IFEX 21 September 2004 |accessdate=17 July 2007 }}</ref>
After this Storsjö offered the website the services of his servers in his web hotel. Finnish Foreign Minister [[Erkki Tuomioja]] then wrote in his own website, after he found out about the existence of the website on a Finnish server, that “''[in Finland] measures were taken immediately to close down the website''” and that the website had now been closed down.<ref>{{cite web |title= Tuomioja verkkosivullaan Kaukaasia-nettisivujen sulkemisesta ‘Tuomioja on his website about Caucasian website having been closed down’ |url= http://formin.finland.fi/public/default.aspx?contentid=62549&nodeid=15642&contentlan=1&culture=fi-FI |publisher= Finnish Foreign Ministry, 2006 |accessdate= |language= Finnish }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
{{cquote|One cannot accept in the name of freedom of speech any materials on the television, in the newspapers or in the internet in which people are incited to murder the president of a foreign nation or in which people who commit suicide bombings are praised.|Erkki Tuomioja}}
Later Tuomioja stated that the ''actions by the authorities may have been initiated at the same time or after the information about the opening of the website was passed on to the foreign minister, but these actions were not based on any instructions from the Foreign Ministry, to whose jurisdiction they do not by any means belong.''<ref>{{cite web |title=Ulkoministeriö ei ohjeistanut sivuston tutkintaa ‘The Foreign Ministry did not give instructions about investigating the website’ |url=http://www.finrosforum.fi/Document/KC/HS_22_10_2004_Ulkoministerio_ei_ohjeistanut.htm |publisher=[[Helsingin Sanomat]] 22 October 2004 |accessdate=17 July 2007 |language=Finnish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928051025/http://www.finrosforum.fi/Document/KC/HS_22_10_2004_Ulkoministerio_ei_ohjeistanut.htm |archivedate=28 September 2007 |df= }}</ref>
According to the acting head of the FSIS, Mr. Hannu Moilanen, the actions of the security intelligence service were approved from a high level: ''We were in good co-operation with the head of the state, who blessed our actions and considered them quite necessary.''<ref>{{cite web |title=Tshetsheenisivusto suljettiin Suomen hallituksen tuella ‘The Chechen website was closed down with approval from the Finnish government’ |url=http://www.finrosforum.fi/Document/KC/HS_14_10_2004_hallituksen_tuella.htm |publisher=[[Helsingin Sanomat]] 14 October 2004 |accessdate=17 July 2007 |language=Finnish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928051012/http://www.finrosforum.fi/Document/KC/HS_14_10_2004_hallituksen_tuella.htm |archivedate=28 September 2007 |df= }}</ref>
The Finnish Security Intelligence Service first asked the internet operator [[TeliaSonera]] to disconnect Storsjö’s server from the web. TeliaSonera did not agree to this, since in their opinion the Chechen rebels website did not break any law.<ref>{{cite web |title=Operaattori: Tshetsheenien internetsivut eivät rikkoneet lakia ‘Operator: The website of the Chechens did not break law |url=http://www.finrosforum.fi/Document/KC/HS_20_10_2004_Operaattori.htm |publisher=[[Helsingin Sanomat]] 20 October 2004 |accessdate=17 July 2007 |language=Finnish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928051044/http://www.finrosforum.fi/Document/KC/HS_20_10_2004_Operaattori.htm |archivedate=28 September 2007 |df= }}</ref>
After this the Finnish Security Intelligence Service asked Storsjö to remove the Kavkaz Center website from his server, but Storsjö refused to do this, citing freedom of speech as his grounds. On the following day representatives of the Security Intelligence Service went to see an associate of Storsjö in order to discuss the matter, and the associate handed the server over to the Security Intelligence Service so that they could investigate it.<ref>{{cite web |author=Heikki Saari |title=Supo vastaan Storsjö, Sananvapauden soturi ‘Security Intelligence Service vs Storsjö, champion of free speech’ |url=http://www.seura.fi/?id=4734 |publisher=Seura |accessdate=18 April 2007 |language=Finnish}}</ref>
Due to these events, president of the Committee on Constitutional Matters of the [[Parliament of Finland|Finnish Parliament]], MP [[Kimmo Sasi]] submitted a written question to the government on the actions of the Security Intelligence Service, to which [[Minister of the Interior (Finland)|Minister of the Interior]], Mr. [[Kari Rajamäki]] replied, “that there was nothing in the actions of the Security Intelligence Service that would merit a reprimand.”<ref>{{cite news | url =http://www.digitoday.fi/page.php?page_id=11&news_id=200415940 | title = Tshetsheenien sivut julki ‘Chechen website cleared for publication’ | accessdate = 2007-04-18 | location= | date= | work= Digitoday | first= Markku | last= Pervilä }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url =http://www.eduskunta.fi/faktatmp/utatmp/kk_808_2004.htm | title = KIRJALLINEN KYSYMYS 808/2004 Ns. tshetsheenisivujen sulkeminen ‘Written question 808/2004, so called closing down of the Chechen website’ | accessdate =17 July 2007 | location= | date= | work=Eduskunta ‘[[Parliament of Finland|Finnish Parliament]]’ | first= Kimmo | last= Sasi }}</ref>
During his visit to Finland, Russian Prime Minister [[Mikhail Fradkov]] thanked Finnish Prime Minister [[Matti Vanhanen]] for having closed down the Kavkaz Centerin website.<ref>{{cite news | url =http://www.ts.fi/arkisto/haku.aspx?ts=1,0,0,0:0:261279,0 | title =Pääministerit vauhdittivat neuvotteluja Saimaan kanavasta |trans-title=Prime Minister Speed up Negotiations about the Saimaa Canal | accessdate =18 April 2007 | location= | date= | work=[[Turun Sanomat]] | first= STT ([[Suomen Tietotoimisto]]) | last= }}</ref> When it was no longer possible to operate in Finland, Storsjö transferred Kavkaz Center to his servers in [[Sweden]], but when it was found out that the website was legal in Finland, he opened it on his Finnish servers.
The Russian ambassador to Finland, Mr. [[Vladimir Grinin]] then asked Finnish members of Parliament why it was allowed in Finland to keep the Kavkaz Center website on Finnish servers and nothing had been done about it. On the basis of discussion carried out by members of the public, the MPs answered him that freedom of speech is in force in Finland and that politicians cannot interfere with websites so long as no law is broken.<ref>{{cite news | url =http://www.finrosforum.fi/Document/KC/HS_19_11_2004_Venajan_lahettilas.htm | title =Venäjän lähettiläs kyseli kansanedustajilta tshetsheenisivuista ‘Russian Ambassador Asked Members of Parliament About Chechen Website’ | accessdate =2007-11-11 | location = | date =18 July 2007 | work =[[Helsingin Sanomat]] 19 November 2004 | first =STT ([[Suomen Tietotoimisto]]) | last = | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070928051019/http://www.finrosforum.fi/Document/KC/HS_19_11_2004_Venajan_lahettilas.htm | archivedate =28 September 2007 | df = }}</ref>
Storsjö has also been involved in arm wrestling with the authorities and the Russian ambassador in Sweden. However, both a court of law and the [[Chancellor of Justice]] have ruled that the contents of the website are legal and that there are no grounds on which it should be closed down.
The great amount of publicity that kavkazcenter.com got in Finland and the significance of these developments have to do with the principle of freedom of speech and questions relating to it, and thus the case was widely commented upon in the editorials of Finnish newspapers and elsewhere in the media.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sananvapautta loukkaava lopetus ‘A Closing Down That Violates Free Speech’ |url=http://www.ts.fi/arkisto/haku.aspx?ts=1,0,0,0:0:260125,0 |publisher=[[Turun Sanomat]], 22 October 2004 |accessdate=19 July 2007 |language=Finnish}}</ref> This discussion has helped to draw the line at which the authority of courts of law and the police ends in matters relating to freedom of speech.
==Alleged Financial Support for Chechen Terrorists== Storsjö said in May 2005 an interview with [[Turun Sanomat]] that he is collecting money through donations that anyone can make to an association called “Support for information service on the Caucasus”, from which moneys are directed to the support of Kavkaz Center. He did, however, admit that the moneys end up with Chechen rebels, among whom there are “elements that have tendencies towards terrorism.”<ref>{{cite web |title= Lehtitieto: Tshetsheeneille aiotaan kerätä Suomesta rahaa (‘Newspaper: Intentions to collect money for Chechens in Finland’) |url= http://www.mtv3.fi/uutiset/txt/kotimaa.shtml/arkistot/kotimaa/2005/05/367231 | publisher= MTV3 | accessdate=2007-04-18 | language=Finnish}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.turunsanomat.fi/kotimaa/?ts=1,3:1002:0:0,4:2:0:1:2005-05-12,104:2:301838,1:0:0:0:0:0: | title = Tshetshenia-sivusto aukeaa perjantaina salaisella palvelimella (‘Chechen web pages to open on Friday on a secret server’) | accessdate = 2005-05-12 | location= | date=12 May 2005 | work=[[Turun Sanomat]] | first= Taneli | last= Heikka | language=Finnish}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://football.guardian.co.uk/Columnists/Column/0,,1684473,00.html | title = Tshetseeneille aloitetaan rahankeruu netissä (‘Collection of money for Chechens to begin in the internet’) | accessdate = 2007-04-18 | location= | date=12 May 2005 | work= Tietokone | first= Satu | last= Summa }}</ref> The matter was first made public by [[Aamulehti]], and Storsjö said that this was a false report, since no association called “Support for information service on the Caucasus” ever has existed. It is not possible to find out anything about this alleged association with the Google search engine, and no such association exists in the Finnish Register for Associations.
==Apprehension on Odessa== [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] authorities apprehended Storsjö in [[Odessa]] on May 26, 2008, because he was on the list of ''[[personae non gratae]]'' in the [[Russian Federation]].<ref>{{cite web |title= Suomalainen Venajä-aktivisti viruu putkassa Odessassa (‘Finnish Activist on Russian Matters Lies in Jail in Odessa’) | url= http://www.uusisuomi.fi/kotimaa/33592-suomalainen-venaja-aktivisti-viruu-putkassa-odessassa | publisher= [[Uusi Suomi]] | accessdate=2008-08-28 | language=Finnish}}</ref> Storsjö was released from jail on May 28, 2007, and the Ukrainian authorities had cause to review their practises concerning lists of ''personae non gratae''.<ref>{{cite web |title= Suomalainen Venäjä-aktivisti saa Ukrainan tarkistamaan kieltolistansa (‘Finnish Activist on Russian Matters causes Ukraine to revise its list of denied entries’) | url= http://www.uusisuomi.fi/kotimaa/33671-suomalainen-venaja-aktivisti-saa-ukrainan-tarkistamaan-kieltolistansa | publisher= [[Uusi Suomi]] | accessdate=2008-08-29 | language=Finnish}}</ref>
==Court Case Concerning Alleged Organisation of Chechens’ Illegal Entry into Finland== In early June 2009, Storsjö declared that he had arranged the entry into Finland of around 50 Chechens who had been living in exile in [[Turkey]]. He said the [[Finnish Border Guard]] suspected him of arranging a gross illegal entry to Finland in April 2009.<ref>{{cite web |title= Tšetšenia-aktivisti: Olen pääepäilty maahantulojutussa (‘Chechnya Activist: I am the main suspect in a case of illegal entry’) | url= http://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/artikkeli/Tšetšenia-aktivisti+Olen+pääepäilty+maahantulojutussa/1135246501172 | publisher= [[Helsingin Sanomat]] | accessdate=2009-06-06 | language=Finnish}}</ref>
In a court case that began on March 24, 2011, in the [[Vantaa Local Court]], the prosecutor Mikko Sipila accused Storsjö altogether of three cases of arranging an illegal entry, of which one he considered to be a gross one. He demanded that Storsjö be given a jail sentence. The alleged crimes had taken place from 2007 to 2010. According to the prosecution, Storsjö had brought 22 Chechens from Turkey to Finland on three separate occasions, and 9 of these people had been minors. None of these people had carried travel documents that would have entitled them to enter Finland. The prosecution also deemed that even though Storsjö had not benefited from this activity financially, he had reaped benefits in other ways, such as gaining a reputation and the respect of certain circles.”
Storsjö denied having benefited from gains in reputation. He had publicly disclosed his activities only after the Border Guard had released statements to the effect that they suspected him of committing crimes. In fact he had only had losses from his activism, since he had paid the air fares of the Chechens from [[Istanbul]] via [[Helsinki]] to [[St. Petersburg]] from his own and his company’s funds. Storsjö denied having broken Finnish law. According to him the criminal law allows the arrangement of entry to foreigners when there are acceptable grounds for such action. “I have decided to help these people, and I have done so fully conscious of the risks on my part.”<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/artikkeli/Syytt%C3%A4j%C3%A4+vaatii+t%C5%A1et%C5%A1eenej%C3%A4+Suomeen+auttaneelle+vankeutta/1135264058800 | title = Tšetšeenien auttajaa uhkaa vankeusrangaistus (‘Helper of Chechens Threatened by a Jail Sentence’) | accessdate = 2011-02-25 | location= Helsinki | date=25 February 2011 | work='' [[Helsingin Sanomat]], p. A7| first= Irina| last= Vähäsarja }}</ref>
The court case concluded on May 9, 2011. Storsjö was acquitted of all charges. The court held that his activity had not been of criminal kind, but that there had been acceptable grounds for it. The judge referred to the same section of the law that Storsjö had cited in court. The judge considered that Storsjö’s grounds for his activity were credible: this was a case of humanitarian activity based on empathy. The judge considered that the Chechens really were in need of protection, since nearly all of them had already been awarded asylum in Finland. The judge also considered that Storsjö had not benefited personally from his activism; on the contrary, he had received various threats because of it.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/artikkeli/T%C5%A1et%C5%A1eenej%C3%A4+Suomeen+auttaneen+syytteet+hyl%C3%A4ttiin/1135265992959 | title = Tšetšeenien auttaminen ei ollut rikos (‘Helping Chechens Was Not a Crime’) | accessdate = 2011-05-10 | location= Helsinki | date=2011-05-10| work='' [[Helsingin Sanomat]], p. A10 | first= Irina | last= Vähäsarja }}</ref>
The prosecutor had stated that he shall appeal the decision and the case may yet continue in the [[Hovrätt]], that is, The Court of Appeals.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/artikkeli/Syytt%C3%A4j%C3%A4+tyytym%C3%A4t%C3%B6n+t%C5%A1et%C5%A1eenien+auttajan+tuomioon/1135266196066 | title = Syyttäjä tyytymätön tšetšeenien auttajan tuomioon (‘Prosecutor Not Happy With Decision On Chechens’ Helper’) | accessdate = 2011-06-06 | location= Helsinki | date=12 January 2006 | work=[[Helsingin Sanomat]] | language=Finnish}}</ref> In June 2012, it reversed the lower court's decision and handed down a four-month [[suspended sentence]], ruling that the Chechens were not in danger.<ref name=HS /> Storsjö plans to appeal to the [[Supreme Court of Finland]].
==Political career== Storsjö was a candidate for the [[Green League]] of Finland in [[Helsinki]] in the [[2008 Finnish Municipal Elections|2008 Finnish municipal elections]].<ref>[http://www.storsjo.net/fi/ Storsjo.net] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110315053723/http://storsjo.net/fi/ |date=2011-03-15 }}</ref> He received 106 votes and was not elected.<ref>{{cite web |title=Kuntavaalit 2008 ‘Municipal Elections 2008’ |url= http://yle.fi/vaalit2008/tulospalvelu/ehdokkaat/ehdokas_kno91_ehdno227.html |publisher= [[YLE]] |accessdate=25 February 2011 |language=Finnish}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.turunsanomat.fi/kotimaa/?ts=1,3:1002:0:0,4:2:0:1:2005-05-12,104:2:301838,1:0:0:0:0:0: Mikael Storsjö admits that the moneys go to people who support “terrorists” — Chechya webpages to open on Friday on a secret server.] ([[Turun Sanomat]]; Published May 12, 2005 4:00:38)

[[Outsourcing]] has been a growing area for business. It is primarily associated with 'support functions' such as [[Information technology|IT]], [[Human resources|HR]] or [[accounting]]. [[Marketing]] outsourcing, whilst common in the [[United States|US]], has not yet been embraced by British industry, but the [[economic downturn]] means that many businesses may well look to this form of cost reduction.<ref>[http://hbswk.hbs.edu/item/4883.html Should You Outsource Your Marketing?]. ''Harvard Business School. 2005-007-04.''</ref> Increased interest in an Outsourced Marketing Department subscription is also being driven by the rapid and continuous expansion of tactics requiring specialized expertise. This includes specialties such as video production, online marketing, online search optimization, custom programming and integration of online marketing platforms with company functions such as sales, recruitment and finance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ilyapozin/2014/04/23/leave-it-to-the-experts-should-you-outsource-your-marketing/#56f9bc8d2393|title=Leave It To The Experts: Should You Outsource Your Marketing?|website=www.forbes.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-11}}</ref>
== Benefits == Outsource marketing is the art of handing over the entire marketing demands of a company to a third party. This offers several distinct benefits:
Firstly companies can access higher quality talent that they might ordinarily be able to attract into an in-house department.
Secondly, outsourcing negates the need for an in-house team, thus reducing [[Overhead (business)|overhead]] – clients can literally operate with a bare bones marketing team, or even none at all. Some firms are marketing savings of 20% versus in-house hiring.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rsmconnect.com|title=RSM Marketing {{!}} Outsourced Marketing Department|website=RSM Connect|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-11}}</ref>
Thirdly, outsourcing reduces or eliminates the need for multiple, biased specialist agencies – all the marketing requirements are catered for by one centralised agency offering media-neutral and discipline-neutral marketing.
Lastly, this enables companies to move fast, with access to the exact resources they need to complete the ever-changing requirements to stay ahead in dynamic markets. Outsourcing gives immediate access, eliminating the delays of locating, vetting, negotiating and engaging with new resources/vendors.
== Options ==
=== Employee augmentation === Not all business owners choose to outsource due to a hectic overload of work at the office. Staff augmentation is utilised when a company decides to outsource tasks to a more skilled candidate while enjoying the flexibility of paying on an as-needed basis.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://think-moa.com.au/employee-augmentation-marketing-outsourcing/|title=Employee Augmentation – Marketing Outsourcing - THiNK - Marketing Operations Advisory|website=think-moa.com.au|language=en-AU|access-date=2017-12-05}}</ref>
=== Project-based outsourcing === Project-based outsourcing is applicable to companies that only have irregular tasks needing completion or a project needed as a one-time event. Companies elect to outsource projects in this manner so they are able to continue their focus on their own business operations with little or no interruption.
=== Contracting/out-tasking === Contracting is a similar process to that of staff augmentation. The labour involved is arranged on an hourly, daily, weekly or monthly schedule allowance. The contracting approach involves the transfer process of a service to the selected outsourcing partner. The out-tasking arrangement is most suitable for business owners that wish to keep control over the entire process.
=== Managed outsourcing services === The managed services option enables the management of company operations by a third party participant on behalf of the company itself. The managed service provider takes control of all operations and projects and assumes ongoing responsibility within the company. Some providers offer this as a subscription service, setting a flat monthly fee and shifting priorities to keep the workload within the agreed upon range of resource hours.
=== Offshore outsource === In this outsourcing method, as the name suggests, companies seek contractors from offshore locations to complete projects for them. An example of this method is Australian companies offshoring their call centre operators to workers in the Philippines. This option allows for reduced expenditure while maintaining efficiency and control over the entire procedure.
Businesses and [[brand]]s can achieve all of these benefits with the added bonus of flexibility (up-weighting or downscaling the requirements at any point), which suits the uncertainty of the [[economic environment]].
Marketing outsourcing should not be confused with [[sales outsourcing]] or working with a contract sales organization.
The challenging economic backdrop has meant that major corporations have begun outsourcing significant parts of their marketing. For instance, the [[Guardian newspaper]] outsourced most of their marketing design in May 2010.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/may/17/guardian-news-and-media | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Jason | last=Deans | title=Guardian News & Media to outsource marketing design services | date=17 May 2010}}</ref>
{{Expand section|date=April 2011}}

{{Infobox officeholder | honorific-prefix = [[The Right Honourable]] | name = The Lord Thomson of Fleet | honorific-suffix = [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the British Empire|GBE]] | image = Roy Thomson Cropped.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Roy Herbert Thomson | birth_date = {{birth date|1894|6|5}} | birth_place = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada | death_date = {{death date and age|1976|8|4|1894|6|5}} | death_place = [[London]], [[England]] | known_for = Established Radio station [[CKFX-FM|CFCH]] (1931), Acquired [[Timmins Daily Press]] (1934), Successful newspaper and other media entrepreneur. | spouse = Edna Annis Thomson (nee Irvine) (m. 1916, d. 1951) | children = 3 }}
'''Roy Herbert Thomson, 1st Baron Thomson of Fleet''', [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the British Empire|GBE]] (June 5, 1894 – August 4, 1976) was a [[Canadian]] [[newspaper]] proprietor who became one of the moguls of [[Fleet Street]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Roy-Herbert-Thomson-1st-Baron-Thomson|title=Roy Herbert Thomson, 1st Baron Thomson {{!}} British publisher|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2017-07-10|language=en}}</ref>
He first came to prominence when he was selling radios in Ontario, and to give his customers more programmes to listen to, decided to launch his own radio station. He then moved into newspapers, buying ''[[The Scotsman]]'' as a salute to his Scottish ancestors, followed by the first Scottish independent television channel. By 1966, he owned both ''[[The Times]]'' and ''[[The Sunday Times]]''.
==Early life== On June 5, 1894, Thomson was born as Roy Herbert Thomson in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada. Thomson's father was Herbert Thomson, a telegraphist turned barber who worked at Toronto's Grosvenor Hotel (at Yonge and Alexander - now site of Courtyard Marriott), and [[England|English]]-born Alice Maud.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.geni.com/people/Roy-Herbert-Thomson-1st-Baron-Thomson-of-Fleet-GBE/6000000014718209357|title=Roy Herbert Thomson, 1st Baron Thomson of Fleet, GBE|website=[[geni.com]]|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref> Thomson's family lived at 32 Monteith Street, off Church Street in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]]. Thomson's paternal grand-parents were Hugh Thomson and Mary Nichol Sylvester. Thomson's grand-father Hugh was one of ten children of George Thomson, son of Archibald Thomson, who emigrated from Westerkirk, Scotland to Canada in 1773. Archibald was brother of [[David and Mary Thomson|David Thomson]], first European settler of [[Scarborough, Toronto|Scarborough]], [[Ontario]].
Thomson’s ancestors were small tenant farmers on the estates of the Dukes of Buccleuch at [[Bo'ness]], in the parish of [[Westerkirk]], [[Dumfriesshire]], [[Scotland]]. Thomson's ancestor, Archibald Thomson (born May 1749), migrated to [[British North America]] in 1773, marrying Elizabeth McKay, of [[Quebec City|Quebec]]. The family eventually settled in [[Upper Canada]], but retained a sentimental attachment to their country of origin.
==Career== During [[World War I]], Roy Thomson attended a [[business college]], and owing to bad eyesight he was rejected by the army. He went to [[Manitoba]] after the war to become a [[farmer]], but was unsuccessful. Thomson travelled to Toronto again, where he held several jobs at different times; one of which was selling radios. However, he found selling radios difficult because the only district left for him to work in was [[Northern Ontario]]. In order to give his potential customers something to listen to he undertook to establish a radio station. By quite a stroke of luck, he was able to procure a radio frequency and transmitter for $201. [[CKFX-FM|CFCH]] officially went on the air in [[North Bay, Ontario]] on March 3, 1931. He sold radios for quite some time after that, but his focus gradually shifted to his radio station, rather than the actual radios.
In 1934, Thomson acquired his first newspaper. With a down payment of $200 he purchased the ''[[Timmins Daily Press]]'', in [[Timmins, Ontario]]. He began an expansion of both radio stations and newspapers in various Ontario locations in partnership with fellow Canadian, [[Jack Kent Cooke]]. In addition to his media acquisitions, by 1949 Thomson was the owner of a diverse group of companies, including several ladies' [[hairstyling]] businesses, a fitted kitchen manufacturer, and an [[ice-cream cone]] manufacturing operation. By the early 1950s, he owned 19 newspapers and was president of the Canadian Daily Newspaper Publishers Association, and then began his first foray into the British newspaper business by starting up the ''Canadian Weekly Review'' to cater to expatriate Canadians living in Britain.
In 1952, Thomson move to [[Edinburgh]] and purchased ''[[The Scotsman]]'' newspaper. In 1957, Thomson launched a successful bid for the [[ITV Network|commercial television]] franchise for Central Scotland, named [[Scottish Television]], which he was to describe as a "permit to print money" (often misquoted as a "licence to print money"). In 1959, Thomson purchased the Kemsley group of newspapers, the largest in Britain, which included ''[[The Sunday Times (UK)|The Sunday Times]]''. Over the years, Thomson expanded his media empire to include more than 200 newspapers in Canada, the [[United States]], and the [[United Kingdom]]. His [[Thomson Organization]] became a [[multinational corporation]], with interests in [[publishing]], [[printing]], [[television]], and [[travel]]. In 1966, Thomson bought ''[[The Times]]'' newspaper from members of the [[Astor family]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2006/jun/13/guardianobituaries.media|title=Lord Thomson of Fleet|last=Goodman|first=Geoffrey|date=2006-06-12|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-07-10|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
In the 1970s, Thomson joined with [[J. Paul Getty]] in a [[consortium]] that successfully explored for [[Petroleum|oil]] in the [[North Sea]].
A modest man, who had little time for pretentious displays of wealth, in Britain he got by virtually unnoticed, riding the [[London Underground]] to his office each day. Nonetheless, he made his son Kenneth promise to use the hereditary title that he had received in 1964, if only in the [[London]] offices of the firm.
[[File:Toronto - ON - Roy Thomson Hall.jpg|thumb|right|[[Roy Thomson Hall]] in the downtown [[Toronto Entertainment District|Entertainment District]] is named after Roy Thomson]]
== Personal life == On 29 Jul 1916, Thomson married Edna Annis Irvine (1895-1951) in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada. Edna A. Irvine was the daughter of John Irvine and Rebecca Caldwell. <ref>{{cit web |url=https://www.geni.com/people/Edna-Thomson/6000000014718308066 |title=Edna Alice Irvine |publisher=[[Geni.com]] |accessdate=October 5, 2018}}</ref>. <ref name="Edna">{{cit web |url=http://www.glendinning.name/ancestry/thomsfam/pafg80.htm#2511 |title=Descendants of Adam THOMSON and Margaret CRANSTOUN |publisher=glendinning.name |accessdate=October 5, 2018}}</ref> Thomson had three children: [[Kenneth Thomson, 2nd Baron Thomson of Fleet|Kenneth Roy Thomson]] (b. 1 Sep 1923), Irma Jacqueline Thomson (b. 20 Oct 1918) and Phyllis Audrey Thomson (b. 6 Jul 1917). <ref name="Edna"/>
On 22 Feb 1951 Thomson's wife Edna died in Ft Lauderdale, Florida. <ref name="Edna"/> In 1952, Thomson move to [[Edinburgh]]. In 1976, Thomson died in London, England. A plaque was placed in the crypt of [[St Paul's Cathedral]].
After Thomson's death in 1976, his son [[Kenneth Thomson, 2nd Baron Thomson of Fleet|Kenneth Thomson]] became chair of [[Thomson Corporation]] and inherited the [[baron]]ial title becoming the 2nd [[Baron Thomson of Fleet]]. With the Thomson operations now principally again in Canada, the younger Thomson did not use his title in Canada though he did so in Britain, and used two sets of stationery reflecting this dichotomy. In any case, as the peerage title he had was inherited, it did not debar him from retaining his Canadian citizenship, and he never took up his right to a seat in the pre-1999 [[House of Lords]].
=== Legacy === [[Roy Thomson Hall]], one of [[Toronto]]'s main concert halls, is named in his honour as the Thomson family donated $5.4 million to its construction.
==Honours and styles of address== ===Honours=== In the [[1964 New Year Honours]], it was announced that Thomson would be elevated to the [[peerage]] as a [[Baron]] "for public services".<ref name="LG 31 December 1963">{{London Gazette |issue=43200 |date=31 December 1963 |page=1 |supp=y}}</ref> On 10 March 1964, he was made '''[[Baron Thomson of Fleet]]''', of Northbridge in the City of Edinburgh.<ref name="LG 10 March 1964">{{London Gazette |issue=43267 |date=10 March 1964 |page=2189 }}</ref> In order to receive this title, it was necessary for Thomson to acquire [[British citizenship]], as the Canadian government had made it common practice since 1919 to disallow the conference of titular honours from the sovereign on Canadians. However, the Canadian ''Citizenship Act'' between 1947 and 1977 stated that any Canadian who became a citizen of another country through means other than marriage would cease to be a Canadian citizen. Thus, Thomson lost his [[Canadian citizenship]] in the process.
He was appointed [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the British Empire]] (GBE) in the [[1970 New Year Honours]].<ref name="LG 30 December 1969">{{London Gazette|issue=44999|date=1 January 1970|page=8|supp=y}}</ref>
===Styles of address=== *1894-1964: Mr Roy Thomson *1964-1970: ''The Right Honourable'' The Lord Thomson of Fleet<ref name="LG 31 December 1963"/> *1970-1976: ''The Right Honourable'' The Lord Thomson of Fleet [[Order of the British Empire|GBE]]<ref name="LG 30 December 1969"/>

'''Rupert Sanderson''' (born in 1966 in [[Penang]], [[Malaysia]]) is a British [[shoe]] [[fashion designer|designer]].
==Early life and education== After graduating from [[Royal Holloway and Bedford New College]], [[London University]], Sanderson worked in advertising in London before enrolling on the shoe making course at [[Cordwainers College]] in [[East London]]. Sanderson then worked in Italy first for [[Sergio Rossi]], and later [[Bruno Magli]].
==Career== {{Advert|section|date=June 2015}}Rupert Sanderson produced his first shoe collection in 2001. By way of reinforcing his design principles, in 2006 Sanderson bought a controlling interest in the shoe factory in the outskirts of [[Bologna, Italy]], that he had been working with from his first collection.{{Citation needed|date=June 2015}} Together with Bertrand Mak, Sanderson co-founded R. SANDERSON, the ultra luxury house of his own label distinguished by the signature 24-carat [[Gold leaf|gold leaf]] heels and accessories.
==Achievements and awards== ;2008 * Established Fashion Fringe Shoes <ref>http://www.fashionfringe.co.uk/index1.htm {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090727065727/http://www.fashionfringe.co.uk/index1.htm |date=July 27, 2009 }}</ref> with Colin McDowell's Fashion Fringe organisation. * Designed shoes for Peter Handke’s ''The Hour We Knew Nothing of Each Other'' at the [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]]. * WON [[British Fashion Council]] <ref>http://www.britishfashioncouncil.com/</ref> Accessory Designer of the Year<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britishfashionawards.com/content.aspx?CategoryID=253|title=British Fashion Awards|work=britishfashionawards.com|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref> ;2009 * WON [[Elle Style Awards]] Accessory Designer of the Year<ref>http://www.elleuk.com/styleawards09 {{Dead link|date=June 2015}}</ref> ;2010 * Designed shoes for The Royal Opera's ''[[Aida]]'' for a cast of over 200. Directed by [[David McVicar]].
==Collaborations== * 2008 – Louise Goldin (SS09) * 2009 – [[Karl Lagerfeld]] (AW09) * 2010 – [[Karl Lagerfeld]] (SS10 and AW10) * 2010 - The Royal Opera's ''[[Aida]]'' - [[Giuseppe Verdi]]
==Stores== Rupert Sanderson has a store in [[London]] and opened stores in [[Hong Kong]] and [[Paris]]. The store in London is in [[Mayfair]]; and in Paris at the [[Palais-Royal]]. Rupert Sanderson shoes are also available in over 160 department and specialist stores in fashion capitals around the world.

{{Orphan|date=July 2011}} The '''Thomson Reuters/PayNet Small Business Lending Index''' (SBLI) is an [[economic indicator]] from [[Thomson Reuters Indices]] and PayNet Inc. Because small businesses generally respond to changes in economic conditions more rapidly than larger businesses do, the Thomson Reuters/PayNet Small Business Lending Index serves as a [[leading indicator]] of the economy.
The index, utilizing [[small business]] loan origination data from major lenders, measures the volume of loans to Small Businesses normalized to a base year - 2005. Seasonally adjusted, the index is presented as an absolute as well as by a percent change versus the prior year. It is published monthly as follows:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! width="200pt"|PRELIMINARY data for current value reflecting most recent small business lending activity released ! width="200pt"|REVISED data for month preceding Preliminary released ! width="200pt"|FINAL data for month preceding Revised released |- |}
The index has its highest correlation with GDP change as a leading indicator, leading between 2 and 5 months in advance. The index undergoes periodic checks to examine the accuracy of the estimates over time.{{cn|date=September 2015}}
== Methodology == All data is collected by PayNet, Inc. PayNet collects real-time loan information from more than 350 leading U.S. lenders. Its proprietary database encompasses over 19 million current and historic contracts worth over $1.5 trillion.
PayNet primarily collects data from small business lenders in the United States, conducts research and analysis, develops and implements estimation methodologies and disseminates statistics to customers. Because PayNet receives its source data over time, estimates are routinely revised to reflect more complete source data. Preliminary and Revised estimates are reported as calculated without any reference to previously reported estimates for the same month. In addition, PayNet undertakes periodic studies that examine the accuracy of the estimates over time and for the existence of any systemic overstatement or understatement.
== See also == * [[Thomson Reuters Indices]]

Küchler]] | editing = [[Elliot Graham]] | distributor = [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://time.com/3604784/steve-jobs-movie-universal/ |title=Steve Jobs Movie Scooped Up by Universal |last=Luckerson |first=Victor |work=Time |date=November 25, 2014 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303165719/http://time.com/3604784/steve-jobs-movie-universal/ |archive-date=March 3, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref> | released = {{Film date|2015|09|05|[[Telluride Film Festival|Telluride]]|2015|10|09|United States|2015|11|13|United Kingdom}}<!--FIRST RELEASE DATE TO PUBLIC, NOT WIDE--> | runtime = 122 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 123--><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/steve-jobs-film |title=STEVE JOBS |publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] |date=October 8, 2015 |accessdate=August 18, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305205050/http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/steve-jobs-film |archive-date=March 5, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref> | country = {{plainlist| * United Kingdom * United States }} | language = English | budget = $30 million<ref name="BOM" /> | gross = $34.4 million<ref name="BOM">{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=jobs2015.htm |title=Steve Jobs (2015) |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=February 23, 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.boxofficemojo.com%2Fmovies%2F%3Fid%3Djobs2015.htm&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref> | production companies = {{Plainlist| * [[Legendary Entertainment|Legendary Pictures]] * [[Scott Rudin Productions]] * [[The Mark Gordon Company]] * Decibel Films * [[Cloud Eight Films]] }} }}
'''''Steve Jobs''''' is a 2015 [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[drama (film and television)|drama]] film directed by [[Danny Boyle]] and written by [[Aaron Sorkin]]. Adapted from the [[Steve Jobs (book)|2011 book of the same name]] by [[Walter Isaacson]] as well as interviews conducted by Sorkin, the film is structured into three acts which cover 14 years (1984–1998) in the life of [[microcomputer revolution|personal computing]] [[innovator]] and [[Apple Inc.]] co-founder [[Steve Jobs]], with each act taking place immediately prior to the launch of a key product – the [[Macintosh 128K|Apple Macintosh]], the [[NeXT Computer]] and the [[iMac G3|iMac]]. Jobs is portrayed by [[Michael Fassbender]], with [[Kate Winslet]], [[Seth Rogen]], [[Katherine Waterston]], [[Michael Stuhlbarg]], and [[Jeff Daniels]] in supporting roles.
Development on the project began in 2011 after the rights to Isaacson's book were acquired. Sorkin wrote the screenplay and filming began in January 2015. A variety of actors were considered and cast before Fassbender eventually took the role. Editing was extensive on the project, with editor [[Elliot Graham]] noting that he was working on existing footage while the film was still shooting. [[Daniel Pemberton]] served as the film's composer, with a focus dedicated to dividing the score into three distinguishable sections.
''Steve Jobs'' premiered at the [[Telluride Film Festival|2015 Telluride Film Festival]] on September 5, 2015, and began a [[limited release]] in [[New York City]] and [[Los Angeles]] on October 9, 2015. It opened nationwide in the U.S. on October 23, 2015, to critical acclaim. Individuals close to Jobs such as [[Steve Wozniak]] and [[John Sculley]] would praise the film's performances, but the film also received criticisms for its inaccuracy in some of its scenes. Winslet won a [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe]] and a [[British Academy Film Awards|BAFTA Award]] for Best Supporting Actress and Sorkin won the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Screenplay]] at the [[73rd Golden Globes]], while Fassbender and Winslet received nominations for [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] and [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]], respectively, at the [[88th Academy Awards]].
== Plot == <!-- Per WP:FILMPLOT, plot summaries for featured films are set between 400-700 words. -->In 1984, the [[Macintosh 128K|Apple Macintosh 128K]]'s voice demo fails less than an hour before its unveiling at [[De Anza College|Flint Center]]. [[Apple, Inc.|Apple]] co-founder [[Steve Jobs]] demands engineer [[Andy Hertzfeld]] fix it, threatening to publicly implicate him in the presentation's credits if he does not. Hertzfeld finally suggests faking the demo using the prototype [[Macintosh 512K]] computer.
Jobs rants to marketing executive [[Joanna Hoffman]] about a ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine article exposing his paternity dispute with ex-girlfriend [[Chrisann Brennan]] – he denies he is the father of Brennan's five-year-old daughter, [[Lisa Brennan-Jobs|Lisa]]. Brennan arrives with Lisa to confront him – she is bitter over his denials and his refusal to support her despite his wealth. Jobs bonds with Lisa over her [[MacPaint]] art and agrees to provide more money and a house. Apple co-founder [[Steve Wozniak]] asks Jobs to acknowledge the [[Apple II]] team in his presentation, but Jobs feels that mentioning the computer (which he considers obsolete) is unwise.
By 1988, following the apparent failure of the Macintosh, Jobs has founded a new company, [[NeXT]]. Before the [[NeXT Computer]] launch at the [[War Memorial Opera House]], he spends time with 9-year-old Lisa, but his relationship with Brennan is still strained – he accuses her of irresponsible behavior and of using Lisa to get money from him. Wozniak arrives and predicts the NeXT will be another failure. Jobs confronts him about his public criticism of him, and Wozniak questions Jobs' contributions to computing history. Jobs defends his role as that of a conductor, who directs "musicians" like Wozniak.
Apple CEO [[John Sculley]] demands to know why the world believes he fired Jobs – Jobs was actually forced out by the Apple board, who were resolute on updating the Apple II following the Macintosh's lackluster sales. Jobs lambasted the decision and dared them to cast a final vote on his tenure, despite Sculley's warnings. After Hoffman and Jobs discuss NeXT's unclear direction, she realizes that Jobs has designed the computer to entice Apple to buy the company and reinstate him.
By 1998, Apple has fired Sculley, purchased NeXT, and named Jobs CEO, and Jobs is about to unveil the [[iMac G3|iMac]] at [[Louise M. Davies Symphony Hall|Davies Symphony Hall]]. He is delighted by Hoffman's strong commercial forecasts, but furious that Lisa has allowed her mother to sell the house Jobs bought for them. Hoffman reminds Jobs that he threatened to withhold Lisa's college tuition – Hertzfeld admits that he paid Lisa's tuition and suggested she attend therapy. Wozniak again asks that Jobs credit the Apple II team during the presentation, and again he refuses.
Sculley arrives in secret and the two make amends. Jobs and Sculley discuss Jobs' life as an adopted child, and Jobs admits that his need for control stems from his feelings of powerlessness in being given up. At the behest of Hoffman, Jobs apologizes to Lisa for his mistakes and accepts that he is her father, admitting that he is "poorly made". Lisa watches her father take the stage to introduce the iMac.
== Cast == * [[Michael Fassbender]] as [[Steve Jobs]]: :Co-founder of [[Apple Inc.]]<ref name="cast">{{cite web |url=http://www.cultofmac.com/310397/meet-official-cast-steve-jobs-movie/ |title=Meet the official cast of the Steve Jobs movie |accessdate=July 12, 2015 |last=Hein |first=Buster |date=January 28, 2015 |work=Cultofmac |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160317052105/http://www.cultofmac.com/310397/meet-official-cast-steve-jobs-movie/ |archive-date=March 17, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref> Fassbender acknowledged his lack of physical resemblance to Jobs, but stated that he was more interested in capturing Jobs' essence than his appearance. In regards to how he aimed to depict Jobs, Fassbender stated he aimed to depict Jobs as a "somebody who was passionate about his vision" as opposed to a cruel person.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2015/10/12/michael-fassbender-steve-jobs-interview/73601092/ |first=Bryan |last=Alexander |title=Michael Fassbender portrays 'poorly made' Steve Jobs |date=October 12, 2015 |work=USA TODAY |accessdate=August 18, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160111020933/http://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2015/10/12/michael-fassbender-steve-jobs-interview/73601092/ |archive-date=January 11, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref> * [[Kate Winslet]] as [[Joanna Hoffman]]: :Apple and [[NeXT]] marketing executive and Jobs' confidant in the film.<ref name="cast" /> When discussing her audition for the film, Winslet later commented that she "heard about it through a crew member who I happened to be working with [in Australia on ''[[The Dressmaker (2015 film)|The Dressmaker]]''], I didn't even care what role it was. I just wanted to be in it. Found out the nature of the role. Googled [Hoffman]. Found one picture of her. Got my husband to go to a wig shop. Buy a short-haired dark wig. Stuck it on my head. Sent a photograph of myself to [producer] Scott Rudin. Danny Boyle came to Melbourne and we had a meeting and he gave me the part."<ref name="Labrecque" /> Winslet spent considerable time with [[Joanna Hoffman]] to prepare for the role before production began. She noted that Hoffman "has a softness to her. She came to America as a young woman and achieved a great deal. One thing that was unique about her as a figure in Steve's life was that she didn't need anything from him. She just needed for him to be the best version of himself. And that's what really set their relationship apart from any relationship with all his other colleagues."<ref name="hoffman">{{cite web |url=http://www.vulture.com/2015/08/kate-winslet-on-her-role-in-steve-jobs.html |title=How Kate Winslet Won a Role in Steve Jobs and Managed All That Sorkin Dialogue |accessdate=August 26, 2016 |last=Kachka |first=Boris |date=August 26, 2015 |work=Vulture |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160618180609/http://www.vulture.com/2015/08/kate-winslet-on-her-role-in-steve-jobs.html |archive-date=June 18, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref> Winslet credits Hoffman's difficult childhood (that began in Armenia) with her ability to manage Jobs.<ref name="dbprem" /> {{paragraph break}} On the nature of the relationship between Hoffman and Jobs, Winslet said that she and Fassbender "were able to develop as literally co-workers. I do believe it was very similar to the relationship that Steve and Joanna had. She was like his work wife. She was head of marketing for the Macintosh, and then she stayed with him for his working life. She was an extraordinary, feisty Eastern European person who was pretty much the only person who could actually knock sense into Steve, and she was also kind of an emotional compass." In developing her sense of the character, Winslet stated that she "just wanted to please [Hoffman] as much as I could. How she sounds, and her accent, is fairly complicated. She grew up largely in Armenia, spent some time in Poland, and has Russians in her family, so she has all three accents, but she's been in America since she was a teenager, so she had American rhythms. You know, she really has this accent that goes way up and down. It's almost impossible to copy because of just how singsongy it becomes. So I had to put it into my own register. But we were all doing accents. I mean, Michael's Irish, and he's playing Steve Jobs, for God's sake."<ref name=hoffman/> Finally, Winslet notes that Hoffman "did genuinely love [Jobs]. And spending time with her, when I was figuring out how to play this difficult part, she would become very emotional. She misses him terribly."<ref name="dbprem"/> * [[Seth Rogen]] as [[Steve Wozniak]]: :Co-founder of Apple and creator of the [[Apple II]].<ref name="cast"/> Rogen admitted to not being familiar with Wozniak, let alone knowing he was co-founder of Apple. He met with Wozniak to prepare for the film, specifically picking up his tendency to move his hands around while speaking.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.gq.com/story/steve-jobs-seth-rogen-qa |first=Lauren |last=Larson |title=Seth Rogen on Steve Jobs and Why He Has Mixed Feelings About Biopics |date=October 16, 2015 |work=GQ |accessdate=March 29, 2017 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gq.com%2Fstory%2Fsteve-jobs-seth-rogen-qa&date=2017-03-29 |archive-date=March 29, 2017 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name="BBCwozint">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-31463351 |title=Woz on watches, addiction and being played by Seth Rogen |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |last=Lobel |first=Mark |date=February 15, 2015 |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com%2Fnews%2Ftechnology-31463351&date=2016-09-04 |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=no}}</ref> In regards to Wozniak's relationship with Jobs, Rogen stated that "his feelings towards Jobs were very complex and interesting. Part of it was taking it at face value and part was reading between the lines."<ref name="dbprem" /> Wozniak stated that he felt honored to be portrayed by Rogen in the film.<ref name="anyway" /> * [[Jeff Daniels]] as [[John Sculley]], CEO of Apple from 1983 to 1993<ref name="cast"/> * [[Katherine Waterston]] as [[Chrisann Brennan]], Jobs' former girlfriend and Lisa's mother * [[Michael Stuhlbarg]] as [[Andy Hertzfeld]], a member of the [[Macintosh 128K|original Mac]] team * Makenzie Moss, Ripley Sobo, and [[Perla Haney-Jardine]] as [[Lisa Brennan-Jobs]], Jobs' daughter (depicted her at different ages throughout the film) * [[Sarah Snook]] as [[Andrea Cunningham|Andrea "Andy" Cunningham]], manager of the Macintosh and [[iMac G3|iMac]] launches * Adam Shapiro as [[Avie Tevanian]], software engineer for NeXT and later Apple * [[John Ortiz]] as Joel Pforzheimer, a journalist for ''[[GQ]]'' who interviews Jobs throughout the film<ref name="cast"/>

To distinguish each of the three product launches depicted in the movie, Danny Boyle and cinematographer [[Alwin H. Küchler|Alwin Küchler]] implemented three different film formats: [[16mm film|16mm]] for 1984, [[35 mm film|35mm]] for 1988, and [[Digital cinematography|digital]] for 1998. They also wanted each of the film's three time periods to visually reflect Jobs' own development at the time. For instance, Küchler explains that the filming at [[De Anza College|Flint Center, De Anza college]] for the first act combined the graininess of 16 mm film and setting to accentuate a provisional, spontaneous look – much in the vein of how Jobs is portrayed at that time. The third act, shot with an [[Arri Alexa]] at the [[Davies Symphony Hall]], incorporated an aesthetic and color palette that were intended to be representative of Jobs' own design philosophies of the [[iMac]] and subsequent [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] hardware. Küchler describes his experience filming ''Steve Jobs'' as "brilliant and challenging at the same time", and that the goal was to "make sure that the visuals kept up with the words", in reference to the production's collaboration between Boyle and Sorkin.<ref name="boylewired">{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/2015/10/steve-jobs-danny-boyle-interview/ |title=Why Danny Boyle Filmed Steve Jobs in Three Different Formats |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |date=October 16, 2015 |accessdate=November 17, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.wired.com%2F2015%2F10%2Fsteve-jobs-danny-boyle-interview%2F&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=September 3, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name="kuchlerthalo">{{cite web |url=http://www.thalo.com/articles/view/1143/steve_jobs_dp_alwin_h_kchler_shoots_in_three_acts |title=Steve Jobs DP Alwin H. Costume designer [[Suttirat Anne Larlarb]] says the real Jobs never wore his trademark turtleneck jumper at any of the launches: "The turtleneck was the off book decision. In those 3 actual launches, in real life, he never wore that. In the 1998 portion of the film, in real life he was wearing a dark greyish/brownish suit. We made it for him as a back up idea in case we needed to adhere to it. As we got closer to the time of filming, I thought we'd set up rules for 1984, we'd set up rules for 1988 – there's so much of the film that's about design and he was about design."<ref name="filmdoctor">{{cite web|url=http://filmdoctor.co.uk/2015/12/01/steve-jobs-costume-designer-suttirat-larlarb-in-conversation|title=''Steve Jobs'' costume designer in conversation|website=filmdoctor.co.uk|date=December 1, 2015|accessdate=December 1, 2015|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Ffilmdoctor.co.uk%2F2015%2F12%2F01%2Fsteve-jobs-costume-designer-suttirat-larlarb-in-conversation&date=2016-09-03|archive-date=September 3, 2016|dead-url=no}}</ref> Fassbender also remarked that the historically inaccurate black turtleneck for the third act was intentional, believing that wearing the attire "felt like I had arrived at [Steve Jobs'] vision, that the person had arrived." Fassbender later added that he and [[Danny Boyle]] decided on this look during filming, and wanted to "give the audience kind of a payoff."<ref name="fassbenderhuman">{{cite web |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/01/05/how-michael-fassbender-made-steve-jobs-human.html |title=How Michael Fassbender Made Steve Jobs Human |first=Kevin |last=Fallon |work=[[Daily Beast]] |date=January 5, 2016 |accessdate=January 5, 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.thedailybeast.com%2Farticles%2F2016%2F01%2F05%2Fhow-michael-fassbender-made-steve-jobs-human.html&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=September 3, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name="fassbenderpayoff">{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2016/film/awards/michael-fassbender-portraying-steve-jobs-1201701595/ |title=Michael Fassbender on Finding the Essence of ''Steve Jobs''|first=Jenelle |last=Riley |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=February 11, 2016 |accessdate=February 17, 2016 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fvariety.com%2F2016%2Ffilm%2Fawards%2Fmichael-fassbender-portraying-steve-jobs-1201701595%2F&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=September 3, 2016 |dead-url=no}}</ref>
=== Post-production === London-based studio Union created the film's [[visual effects]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Rosser |first=Michael |url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/union-to-handle-vfx-on-danny-boyles-steve-jobs-biopic/5083638.article?blocktitle=Most-popular&contentID=-1 |title=Union to handle VFX on Danny Boyle's Steve Jobs biopic |work=[[Screen International|ScreenDaily.com]] |date=February 26, 2015 |accessdate=March 3, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6kE6YBsof?url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/union-to-handle-vfx-on-danny-boyles-steve-jobs-biopic/5083638.article?blocktitle=Most-popular&contentID=-1 |archive-date=September 2, 2016 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> According to editor [[Elliot Graham]], extensive film editing took place even before principal photography was completed. During the one-week rehearsal that took place in between production for each of the three acts (shot in chronological order), Graham would work on the existing footage and receive ongoing feedback from Boyle in the editing room. In an interview with ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', Graham said a particular challenge for him was balancing the [[Shot (filmmaking)#Film editing|shot frequency]] and providing enough "visual interventions" to control for Sorkin's dialogue-heavy screenplay. He described approaching each scene as "a series of fight sequences". Michael Fassbender provided multiple versions of his performance as Jobs, which Graham and Boyle would then choose from during [[post-production]].<ref name="boylecrave">{{cite web |url=http://www.craveonline.com/culture/912765-interview-danny-boyle-politics-steve-jobs |title=Interview Danny Boyle on the Politics of ''Steve Jobs''|last=Bibbiani |first=William |work=[[CraveOnline]] |date=October 16, 2015 |accessdate=November 17, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.craveonline.com%2Fculture%2F912765-interview-danny-boyle-politics-steve-jobs&date=2016-09-02 |archive-date=2016-09-02 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name="grahamguild">{{cite web |url=https://www.editorsguild.com/FromTheGuild.cfm?FromTheGuildid=535 |title=From the Guild: Getting to the Core of Apple |last=Feld |first=Rob |publisher=[[Motion Picture Editors Guild]] |date=November 4, 2015 |accessdate=November 17, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.editorsguild.com%2FFromTheGuild.cfm%3FFromTheGuildid%3D535&date=2016-09-02 |archive-date=2016-09-02 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/video/steve-jobs-editing-aaron-sorkin/ |title=Steve Jobs Editor on the Rush of Working With Aaron Sorkin Dialogue |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=November 17, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fvariety.com%2Fvideo%2Fsteve-jobs-editing-aaron-sorkin%2F&date=2016-09-02 |archive-date=2016-09-02 |dead-url=no}}</ref> Graham also said: "Danny would be involved a lot but also take time away. He would say 'if I'm with you the whole time, we'll always have the same opinions because we're on the exact same journey.'"<ref name="FilmDoctor">{{cite web|url=http://filmdoctor.co.uk/2015/12/08/steve-jobs-editor-elliot-graham-in-conversation/|title=''Steve Jobs'' Elliot Graham in conversation|last=Wooding|first=Andy|website=filmdoctor.co.uk|date=December 8, 2015|accessdate=December 8, 2015|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Ffilmdoctor.co.uk%2F2015%2F12%2F08%2Fsteve-jobs-editor-elliot-graham-in-conversation%2F&date=2016-09-02|archive-date=2016-09-02|dead-url=no}}</ref>

(film)|The Man from U.N.C.L.E.]] | prev_year = 2015 | next_title = | next_year = }} [[Daniel Pemberton]] composed the music for the film. Much like the film's visual approach, the score is divided into three distinguishable sections, each corresponding to the intended feel of the act in which the section is heard. "You have the first act which is analog," Pemberton explains, "you have the second act which is orchestral, and you have the third act which is digital." For the first act's composition, Pemberton primarily used analog synthesizers, in particular ones released no later than 1984 – the time the first act takes place – such as the [[Roland SH-1000]] and [[Yamaha CS-80]]. The second act's score is more operatic in nature, matching the setting of the [[War Memorial Opera House|San Francisco Opera House]]. Finally, the third act featured a more introspective score produced entirely digitally to complement its backdrop of the 1998 iMac product launch, and Pemberton correspondingly used his own iMac to compose this section.<ref name="pembertonpop">{{cite web |url=http://www.popmatters.com/feature/a-symphony-in-three-parts-breaking-down-the-steve-jobs-score-with-composer-/ |title=Breaking Down the == Release == ''Steve Jobs'' premiered at the [[Telluride Film Festival|2015 Telluride Film Festival]] on September 5, 2015,<ref name=prvar>{{cite news |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/jobs-michael-fassbender-new-york-film-festival-1201549347/ |title=''Steve Jobs'' Starring Michael Fassbender to Screen at New York Film Festival |work=Variety |date=July 1, 2015 |first=Ramin |last=Setoodeh |accessdate=July 27, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fvariety.com%2F2015%2Ffilm%2Fnews%2Fjobs-michael-fassbender-new-york-film-festival-1201549347%2F&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref> and began a [[limited release]] in [[New York City]] and [[Los Angeles]] on October 9, 2015. It opened [[Wide release|nationwide]] in the U.S. on October 23, 2015.<ref name=early>{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/universal-s-steve-jobs-release-822408 |title=Universal's ''Steve Jobs'' to Release Early in New York, Los Angeles |last=Washington |first=Arlene |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=September 11, 2015 |accessdate=September 12, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hollywoodreporter.com%2Fnews%2Funiversal-s-steve-jobs-release-822408&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name=tweeks>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/universal-tweaks-steve-jobs-release-1201591040/ |title=Universal Tweaks ''Steve Jobs'' Release |last=McNary |first=Dave |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=September 11, 2015 |accessdate=September 12, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fvariety.com%2F2015%2Ffilm%2Fnews%2Funiversal-tweaks-steve-jobs-release-1201591040%2F&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref> The movie also served as the closing film for the 2015 [[BFI London Film Festival#2015|BFI London Film Festival]], approximately one month before its release in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] on November 13, 2015.<ref name="bficlose">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-34544465 |title=Steve Jobs stars Fassbender and Winslet bring London Film Festival to a close |first=Tim |last=Masters |work=[[BBC News]] |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=October 18, 2015 |accessdate=November 21, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com%2Fnews%2Fentertainment-arts-34544465&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref>
''Steve Jobs'' was released digitally on February 2, 2016 and was released on Blu-ray and DVD on February 16, 2016, and includes [[Audio commentary|feature commentary]] from Boyle, Sorkin, and [[Elliot Graham]]. The physical releases contain a 44-minute [[making-of documentary]], ''Inside Jobs: The Making of Steve Jobs'', chronicling the production of the film.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/from-universal-pictures-home-entertainment-steve-jobs-300192869.html |title=From Universal Pictures Home Entertainment: Steve Jobs |agency=[[PR Newswire]] |date=December 15, 2015 |accessdate=December 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151219004802/http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/from-universal-pictures-home-entertainment-steve-jobs-300192869.html |archive-date=2015-12-19 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://appleinsider.com/articles/15/12/16/danny-boyles-steve-jobs-biopic-set-for-feb-2-digital-release-later-on-blu-ray-dvd |title=Danny Boyle's Steve Jobs biopic set for Feb. 2 digital release, later on Blu-ray & DVD |first=Roger |last=Fingas |work=[[Apple Insider]] |date=December 16, 2015 |accessdate=December 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fappleinsider.com%2Farticles%2F15%2F12%2F16%2Fdanny-boyles-steve-jobs-biopic-set-for-feb-2-digital-release-later-on-blu-ray-dvd&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/steve-jobs-inside-jobs-making-steve-jobs-video |title=STEVE JOBS – INSIDE JOBS: THE MAKING OF STEVE JOBS [Additional Material,Blu-ray] |publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] |accessdate=December 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbfc.co.uk%2Freleases%2Fsteve-jobs-inside-jobs-making-steve-jobs-video&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref>
== Reception ==
=== Box office === ''Steve Jobs'' grossed $17.8 million in North America and $16.7 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $34.4 million, against a budget of $30 million.<ref name=BOM />
In its opening weekend in limited release, the film grossed $521,000 from four theaters, for a per theater average of $130,250, beating out ''[[Sicario (2015 film)|Sicario]]'' ($67,000) for the best average theater gross of 2015.<ref name="Limited">{{cite web |last=D'Alessandro |first=Anthony |url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/martian-pan-the-walk-weekend-box-office-1201572119/ |title='Martian' Still Has Fuel In Its Second Frame; 'Pan' Walks Plank; 'Steve Jobs' Popular In NY & LA – Monday Postmortem |work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=October 12, 2015 |accessdate=November 1, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fdeadline.com%2F2015%2F10%2Fmartian-pan-the-walk-weekend-box-office-1201572119%2F&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref> The film began its wide release on October 23, 2015, alongside ''[[The Last Witch Hunter]]'', ''[[Paranormal Activity: The Ghost Dimension]]'', ''[[Rock the Kasbah (film)|Rock the Kasbah]]'', and ''[[Jem and the Holograms (film)|Jem and the Holograms]]''. In its opening weekend, the film was originally projected to gross $11–12 million from 2,491 theaters; however, after grossing just $2.5 million on its first day, it was revised to $7.4 million. It ended up grossing $7.1 million, finishing seventh at the box office.<ref name="opening">{{cite web |last=D'Alessandro |first=Anthony |url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/the-last-witch-hunter-paranormal-activity-goosebumps-box-office-preview-1201589142/ |title=Only ''Goosebumps'' Will Prevail In Five-Pic Logjam – Box Office Preview |work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=October 20, 2015 |accessdate=November 1, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fdeadline.com%2F2015%2F10%2Fthe-last-witch-hunter-paranormal-activity-goosebumps-box-office-preview-1201589142%2F&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref>
On November 10, 2015, just over two weeks after its wide release, Universal pulled the film from 2,072 theaters in the United States.<ref name="usbopulled">{{cite web |url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/11/11/steve-jobs-movie-pulled-from-over-2000-cinemas-in-us-after-flopping-at-box-office-5493699/ |title=Steve Jobs movie pulled from over 2,000 cinemas in US after flopping at box office |first=Caroline |last=Westbrook |work=[[Metro (magazine)|Metro]] |date=November 11, 2015 |accessdate=November 17, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fmetro.co.uk%2F2015%2F11%2F11%2Fsteve-jobs-movie-pulled-from-over-2000-cinemas-in-us-after-flopping-at-box-office-5493699%2F&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref> ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' said the film suffered from fierce competition at the box office, possible public weariness with Jobs and the low profile of Fassbender in the title role, and that the underperformance at the box office could hurt the film's award chances.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.ftcpublications.com/steve-jobs-box-office-stumble-may-hurt-oscar-chances/ |title=Steve Jobs' box-office stumble may hurt Oscar chances |publisher=FTC Publications Newswire |date=October 26, 2015 |accessdate=October 31, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117022205/http://news.ftcpublications.com/steve-jobs-box-office-stumble-may-hurt-oscar-chances/ |archive-date=November 17, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> After his film was pulled from wide release in the U.S., [[Danny Boyle]] expressed disappointment at the box office performance of ''Steve Jobs'', while suggesting that Universal expanded the film's release "too wide too soon" and that the studio's move was "arrogant".<ref name="boylebo">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-34797483 |title=Danny Boyle 'disappointed' over Steve Jobs US box office flop |publisher=[[BBC]] |work=[[BBC News]] |date=November 12, 2015 |accessdate=November 17, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com%2Fnews%2Fentertainment-arts-34797483&date=2016-09-03 |archive-date=2016-09-03 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name="boylearrogant">{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/danny-boyle-says-the-release-strategy-for-steve-jobs-was-arrogant-2015-11?r=UK&IR=T |title=The director of
